title: How to make a power supply - Quora

response.answer_text: These days, commercially made power supplies are so cheap it doesn’t pay to make your own. Linear supplies are easier to make and design but they usually require a properly sized power transformer and heat sinking as they are inefficient. Switch mode power supplies are much more efficient and small and require less heat sinking. But the layout is very critical. You can buy switching DC-DC power modules to do most of the work and then just use a wall wart. I wouldn’t design a power supply these days. just buy some modules from Banggood or T-mart.

Yes, it is possible and, with some basic understanding of electronics and electronic components, not very difficult. BE AWARE it could be dangerous if you’re not familiar with some of the basics. In short you need a few items. A transformer which lowers your input AC line voltage to a level which is suitable for your particular needs.A rectifier circuit which will convert the input AC (Alternating current) into your output DC ( Direct current).A regulator to regulate the output.Some voltage filtering to ‘clean up’ the output voltage.Keep in mind this is a very simple list but it is the basic circuits needed.

Shameless self promotion. Look for ‘Power Supplies Explained’ on Amazon or at the RSGB shop. This is an introduction to the topic aimed at beginners as well as more advanced readers. It deals with the important topic of safety in detail.

Before you do anything, you need to specify what you want - input voltage, output voltage and current, AC or DC, frequency if AC, duty cycle, adjustment, regulation, temperature range, etc. Then look and see if you can buy one ready-made. It might be cheaper than anything you can build. Power supplies often require special transformers, ICs, and other parts that you can’t get. Often the transformers are custom made.
There are many plans on the Internet. You might also check YouTube. Here is a simple one from PopScience. Build a Simple DC Power Supply
